entry.content:
Yesterday, I wrote about Quake and, by extension, Quake 2â€™s lore. You might think that Doomâ€™s original lore is probably really simple, some kind of, scratches on a paper looking concept, and while it certainly began that wayâ€“It also spawned a book. But, one of the reasons I want to visit the lore of the original Dooms, is because the newer Dooms seem â€¦ unclear to me, as to where exactly they are in the timeline. Or, if there even is a timeline. Anyway, letâ€™s dive a little deeper into the 1993 classic, DOOM.


So, basically, all this time, Iâ€™ve been extremely confused about whether or not youâ€™re the same guy in every Doom game ever made. The short answer is: Yes, you are.

But, I feel like I canâ€™t talk about the lore of all of Doom, without quoting the original opening fiction that started it all (quoted from the fandom wiki).

In DOOM, youâ€™re a space marine, one of Earthâ€™s toughest, hardened in combat and trained for action. Three years ago you assaulted a superior officer for ordering his soldiers to fire upon civilians. He and his body cast were shipped to Pearl Harbor, while you were transferred to Mars, home of the Union Aerospace Corporation. The UAC is a multi-planetary conglomerate with radioactive waste facilities on Mars and its two moons, Phobos and Deimos. With no action for fifty million miles, your day consisted of suckinâ€™ dust and watchinâ€™ restricted flicks in the rec room.

For the last four years the military, UACâ€™s biggest supplier, has used the remote facilities on Phobos and Deimos to conduct various secret projects, including research on inter-dimensional space travel. So far they have been able to open gateways between Phobos and Deimos, throwing a few gadgets into one and watching them come out the other. Recently however, the gateways have grown dangerously unstable. Military â€œvolunteersâ€ entering them have either disappeared or been stricken with a strange form of insanityâ€“babbling vulgarities, bludgeoning anything that breathes, and finally suffering an untimely death of full-body explosion. Matching heads with torsos to send home to the folks became a full-time job. Latest military reports state that the research is suffering a small setback, but everything is under control.

A few hours ago, Mars received a garbled message from Phobos. â€œWe require immediate military support. Something fragginâ€™ evil is coming out of the gateways! Computer systems have gone berserk!â€ The rest was incoherent. Soon afterwards, Deimos simply vanished from the sky. Since then, attempts to establish contact with either moon have been unsuccessful.

You and your buddies, the only combat troop for fifty million miles were sent up pronto to Phobos. You were ordered to secure the perimeter of the base while the rest of the team went inside. For several hours, your radio picked up the sounds of combat: guns firing, men yelling orders, screams, bones cracking, then finally silence. Seems your buddies are dead.

Things arenâ€™t looking too good. Youâ€™ll never navigate off the planet on your own. Plus, all the heavy weapons have been taken by the assault team leaving you only with a pistol. If only you could get your hands around a plasma rifle or even a shotgun you could take a few down on your way out. Whatever killed your buddies deserves a couple of pellets in the forehead. Securing your helmet, you exit the landing pod. Hopefully you can find more substantial firepower somewhere within the station.

As you walk through the main entrance of the base, you hear animal-like growls echoing throughout the distant corridors. They know youâ€™re here. Thereâ€™s no turning back now.

Now, I know what youâ€™re thinking, â€œThis game came before Quake, and it already has a much more fleshed out story?â€ Yeah, kinda weird, right? It continues on like this, into a book, onto Earth, as the invasion of Hell continues, into Doom 64 where you return to Hell, then to Doom 2016 where youâ€™re â€¦ entombed, and then awoken in an alternate reality, and it just keeps going.

I remember when I was a kid, I was only partially aware of all this lore. In fact, I think the only thing I paid attention to was the Doom guy holding his rabbitâ€™s severed head at the end of the game. Oh, and the nightmares I had where, in the middle of the night, I actually hallucinated Lost Souls flying in and out of my room, and it was terrifying at the time (I think I was forced to take a break from the game at this point).

But did you know Doom guy had a family? And that family was murdered by Demons? Did you know there was a theatrical recreation of Doom that starts off with transphobia, and then explains away the demons completely by being like, â€œOh, no itâ€™s not demons. Itâ€™s humans infected with another chromosome.â€ I didnâ€™t like that movie much, aside from the strange inclusion of the game-devâ€™s names, as characters, in the movie.

Did you know that, according to the official Doom book, the Doom marineâ€™s name is Corporal Flynn Taggart? Iâ€™m not sure this is ever held up as canon anywhere else, but itâ€™s a neat little tidbit. The book itself had two nebula nominees, and hereâ€™s the synopsis for you â€¦

The Gates were there on Phobos when mankind first arrived. Inert, unyielding, impossibly alien constructs, for twenty years they sat lifeless, mute testaments to their long-vanished creators, their secrets hidden. Then one day, they sprang to life . . .

Meet Corporal Flynn Taggart, United States Marine Corps; serial number 888-23-9912. Heâ€™s the best warrior the twenty-first century has to offer, which is a damn good thing. Because Flynn Taggart is all thatâ€™s standing between the hell that just dropped in on Mars and an unsuspecting planet Earth . . .

Iâ€™m more quoting, and reflecting on all of this, because, Iâ€™m just now really discovering just how much lore there actually is behind Doom, and finding that it really doesnâ€™t need a whole lot of discussion and deep dives. But, I do think I want to finally read that book.

Never-the-less, this is kind of where my obsession with gaming really started. Sure, there was Wolfenstein 3D, Blake Stone, Commander Keen, Ja â€¦ Jazz JackRabbit? But then there was DOOM. And then fond memories watching my Dad play Quake FTP multiplayer against one of his friends, and then me being absolutely badass in Quake 2 multiplayer â€¦ and then finding I SUCKED HARD in Quake 3 multiplayer (because they completely changed the way the game felt, controlled, and aimed).

My entire childhood was me, waiting for school to be over, so that I could dive back into one of these games. And, despite my delve into coding at the age of 39, I find it strange I never just, you know, started making my own games. At least, until I started making this Mafia Wars clone, that I absolutely am not going to continue, because I donâ€™t think I have the correct know-how to securely store peopleâ€™s usernames and passwords on an encrypted database, on a server that canâ€™t easily be hacked. But â€¦ maybe there is room for something else.

(Yes, this is an actual semi-functional clone of Mafia Wars, that can only be played by me, on my HDD, and I will never release it to the public lol)

entry.title: 28 Years Later, Letâ€™s Look At Quakeâ€™s Lore

link.title: 28 Years Later, Letâ€™s Look At Quakeâ€™s Lore

entry.content:
So, today, I was playing Quake 1 and 2, and something ocurred to me, that hadnâ€™t ever ocurred to me in the 28 to 30 years that these games have been a thing: Iâ€™ve never fully understood what in the hell the story is supposed to be. Obviously, weâ€™re going to skip Quake 3, not because it isnâ€™t good (itâ€™s one of the greatest arena shooters of all time), but because its story is more that of Unreal Tournament. In that, itâ€™s just people from different dimensions fighting in nonstop deathmatch.

But â€¦ if youâ€™ve ever seen those memes online where people poke fun at games where theyâ€™re like, â€œHey, whoâ€™s John Darksouls?â€ and someoneâ€™s like, â€œHeâ€™s the main character of Dark Souls, cousin of John Halo.â€ â€¦ Youâ€™re going to love the story behind Quake 1.

The background, according to the Wiki.

You get the phone call at 4 a.m. By 5:30 youâ€™re in the secret installation. The commander explains tersely, â€œItâ€™s about the Slipgate device. Once we perfect these, weâ€™ll be able to use them to transport people and cargo from one place to another instantly.

â€œAn enemy codenamed Quake, [sic] is using his own slipgates to insert death squads inside our bases to kill, steal, and kidnap.

â€œThe hell of it is we have no idea where heâ€™s from. Our top scientists think Quakeâ€™s not from Earth, but another dimension. They say Quakeâ€™s preparing to unleash his real army, whatever that is.

â€œYouâ€™re our best man. This is Operation Counterstrike and youâ€™re in charge. Find Quake, and stop him â€¦ or it â€¦ You have full authority to requisition anything you need. If the eggheads are right, all our lives are expendable.â€

But thatâ€™s not all!

While scouting the neighborhood, you hear shots back at the base. Damn, that Quake bastard works fast! He heard about Operation Counterstrike, and hit first. Racing back, you see the place is overrun. You are almost certainly the only survivor. Operation Counterstrike is over. Except for you.

You know that the heart of the installation holds a slipgate. Since Quakeâ€™s killers came through, it is still set to his dimension. You can use it to get loose in his hometown. Maybe you can get to the asshole personally. You pump a round into your shotgun, and get moving.

And thatâ€™s it! I mean, obviously, it continues a bit into the actual game, where youâ€™re traversing different dimensions and collecting runes â€¦ killing enemies like something out of Lovecraft, but in its most basic sense, and I mean no offense to those who worked or work for ID Software and on this game, but if I didnâ€™t know what Quake was, I would assume this was a sixth graderâ€™s creative writing homework. I mean, it just starts talking at you, as if you already know whatâ€™s going on? It starts out in 2nd-person perspective and never leaves that narrative. And then thereâ€™s â€œOperation Counterstrike,â€ which makes me wonder where the original devs behind CounterStrike got their gameâ€™s name from.

Especially because Team Fortress was originally a Quake multiplayer mod made by the community (in the 90s).

I wanted to read through all of this, because I also didnâ€™t understand the connection between this game, and the second game, where weâ€™re suddenly invading the Stroggâ€™s home planet, and thereâ€™s me thinking, â€œWho the heck are the Strogg, again?â€

The short answer to that question, is: The Strogg and Quake 2 have almost nothing to do with Quake 1. Itâ€™s a restart, and I kind of found that a little disappointing. The theme of Quake 1 is really cool, and it feels a bit more linked to Doom in the way it handles its world â€¦ even if the lore really leaves something to be desired.

Quake 2â€™s basic lore (via this Wiki):

Quake II takes place in a futuristic sci-fi environment. During the single player campaign, you take the role of a Marine called Bitterman, taking part in â€œOperation Alien Overlordâ€, attempting to save Earth from the Strogg invasion by counter-attacking their planet, Stroggos. During the first attack on Stroggos, the Big Gun strikes down most of the Marine pods with a powerful EMP blast. This causes most of the pods to crash land (many miles from their target landing zones). Most of the Marines are captured or killed, but Bitterman is one of the lucky few to survive. He finds himself many miles from the Big Gun in a Strogg base on the outskirts of the city.

It almost sounds like they retconned the enemyâ€™s name to be Strogg, (pronounced stroeg), rather than John Quake, the main antagonist of planet Quake, from Quake.

And I guess, if you think of it in that way, it makes a little more sense. The Strogg invasion of Earth â€¦ could be considered parallel to â€œQuakeâ€™sâ€ invasion of a military base, and therefore â€¦ Earth. Maybe. But, Iâ€™m just kind of inserting my own canon into something thatâ€™s been over and done with for decades.

The subsequent games all follow strings of lore from Quake 2 (mostly), and I think only Quake 3 acknowledges Quake 1. Which, again, is a shame. I definitely feel like ID should come back for another full Quake release, and give us some continuity here. Even if it only matters to like â€¦ five people.

I think some of them were called like, â€œJohn Readsâ€ or â€œJohn Booksâ€, wherein theyâ€™d put their name and qualify it with something related to writing or reading. Either way, remember that? Do ya?

Well, I recreated that in a bot, that reads from a spreadsheet of your posts, jumbles it, randomizes it, restructures it, and then posts them semi-logically, to Mastodon.

You can see post_gen_bot on Github.

Now, in my use-case for this, I have it reading from Google Sheets Iâ€™ve generated as backups of every single post Iâ€™ve made to Mastodon since the beginning of 2024, because â€¦ I just didnâ€™t know what to do with all of that, until now. But, Iâ€™m assuming, if you really wanted to, you could feed your old backed-up tweets from a deleted Twitter account, into this bot, and then have it post jumbled nonsense from your posting-past on social media.

Thatâ€™d be kinda neat, right?

Now, this is like the 4th or 5th bot Iâ€™ve made? I donâ€™t know, Iâ€™m losing count already.

But, I have had a little bit of aggression directed toward me via the fediverse. Because, some people just donâ€™t think. They donâ€™t consider what theyâ€™re doing, or read what theyâ€™re targeting. They donâ€™t particularly care if youâ€™ve spent time making something interesting, or neat, and would simply request that you mute, delete, and ban your work.

I donâ€™t make these things to please other people, or to meet your expectations or specific specifications of what you personally believe the fediverse should be. I do this for me. And if you donâ€™t like that, you donâ€™t have to see it.

It reminds me of years back, on another Mastodon account, where I was posting about Tomb Raider and how cool the iteration of the game I was playing, happened to be, and this â€¦ I donâ€™t want to call them â€œextremely online,â€ because there was something else wrong with them, entirely, but this person came into my notifications, and they were like, â€œI donâ€™t care about Tomb Raider, why are you talking about this?â€

And I was taken aback, like â€¦ There are legitimately people out there who fully and completely believe the entire world, and everyone in it, revolves around them, specifically. And thatâ€™s frikken nuts.

I donâ€™t think this is a problem that only exists on Mastodon, though. I think this is wide-spread, across all of social media, and the internet, and itâ€™s only been exasperated by a society that celebrates individualism and isolation, and so on, and so forth. I could go on for hours, but this is a topic for another time.

entry.title: Turning Windows into a Dev Machine

link.title: Turning Windows into a Dev Machine

entry.content:
So, itâ€™s been an interesting week and a half. I started screwing around with Python after spending time casually reading about it, and decided to learn it, hands-on, and I smashed up a slew of interesting things. Then, I started thinking about, despite my love for Linux, and especially Debian, there are some critical things I still donâ€™t have access to while on Linux.

Such as things I use for my creations in Second Life, like Quixel, Marvelous Designer. And how Iâ€™m basically locked to only using Gimp. And, regrettably, there are a few games I want to play that I just canâ€™t. With these things in mind, I decided to mess around and put Windows on my System76 machine. It wasnâ€™t all that painful, because I have all of my important stuff backed up on the cloud, and I donâ€™t mind redownloading games as I decide Iâ€™m interested in playing them.

But â€¦ And this could end up being the reason I decide to just put Linux back onto my PC: Turning Windows into a machine for a developer is a pain in the ass.

From configuring SSH, to realizing I didnâ€™t have OpenSSH, to installing OpenSSH, to configuring PowerShell, to downloading the actual latest version, to screwing with SSH keys, to adding, deleting, adding, deleting, adding, deleting, and adding and deleting about 15 different keys, before I generated a new one, and then manually pasted the key into the authorizations on my Debian server.

Oh, but then thereâ€™s VS Code â€¦ An apparent Microsoft centric developer app, that crashes against a wall as soon as you try to push and sync? Because apparently, or at least in my case, it doesnâ€™t know to use OpenSSH?!

Nevertheless, here I am, with access to all of my games, and every single program I used to use, and also my developer tools setup exactly the same way they were in Pop!_OS.

I do have to say that I really like Pop!_OS, but Iâ€™m not that excited about merging and migrating my entire system to the Rust based COSMIC. I donâ€™t know. I â€¦ kind of like Ubuntu, you know?

All that aside, weâ€™ll see how long this lasts. Despite the shortcomings, Linux is really a revolutionary OS, and Iâ€™ll probably put it all back sometime in the future. Probably when I get tired of the games I wanted to play, and decide to figure out the workarounds for the apps I want to use in Windows (I donâ€™t like using Virtual Machines, I just want to interact with my actual PC).

But, until then, Iâ€™m going to see how far I can stretch Windows into giving me control of the system.
